subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters

messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> Some QS letters have lexical sets assigned to them permanently and
> everyone must use that letter for that lexical set no matter its sound
> it. Period.
>
> *But* some lexical sets may be assigned to different letters
> depending on the speaker's accent.

Yes.

> In the following figure, lexical sets named in black can not be
> moved but those named in gray can have any one of the positions it is
> written in.

CLOTH should be gray; the whole point of it is that some people unify
it with LOT, others with THOUGHT, and still others with both. (For me,
CLOTH = THOUGHT but LOT = PALM.)

> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig1.jpg

Thanks for this chart: it's very helpful.

> Issue 1:
> Exactly which lexical sets should be frozen to a particular QS
> letter and which should be allowed to move? The images I made above
> for Fig 1. is certainly totally inadequate and is really only usable
> for a couple accents.

Actually, it's quite good. These lexical sets aren't complete for every
dialect, but they cover the great majority of the distinctions in the
great majority of dialects.

> Far more lexical sets would have to be able to move to other letters.

Why do you think so?

> Issue 2:
> There can not be some many "re-assignable" lexical sets that a given
> accent can arrange the chart in more than one way. If this were
> possible, people with the same accent would use different letters in
> spelling the same word. Each *person* maybe consistent but within the
> accent there would be wide variation.

That may be so. See Read's strictures against the fetish of standard
spelling. I'm in favor of standard spelling within limits, but I'm
willing to set the limits wider than TO does.

> Issue 3:
> Complexity: Lexical set use is going to be harder to explain than a
> static IPA map.

Not really. You list a number of words that are firmly (that is,
cross-dialectally) in each lexical set as examples. Reed's problem is
that he only lists two words and they aren't all well-chosen.

> I am already completely glossing over how Roe will
> work with lexical sets

There's inevitable arbitrariness there, as there aren't as many vowels
before /r/ as there are otherwise. For example, the vowel in the NEAR
set can be KIT + /r/ or FLEECE + /r/ without any difference in meaning.
For me it's more like FLEECE, and that's the historical value (as you can
see from the spellings "near", "beer", etc. which use forms characteristic
of the FLEECE set), but more people probably use the KIT vowel nowadays.
We can allow the variation or force a single value.

The same is true of SQUARE, which can be DRESS + /r/ or FACE + /r/.
Likewise CURE can be FOOT + /r/ or GOOSE + /r/.

> or how we explain how to assign the set CURE
> with its "invisible" consonantal y.

It's just a fact that the CURE and GOOSE vowels are sometimes preceded
by a consonantal y which is not written in TO. Historically, written
long "u" was always pronounced with a preceding "y"; this "y" has been
lost completely in some dialects, retained in almost all words in some
dialects, and in a third group of dialects retained in some words (like
"cure") but lost in others (like "tune"). So some people will write
Tea-Ye-Ooze-No for "tune", and others will write Tea-Ooze-No (and for
that matter, some will write Cheer-Ooze-No, for their dialects have
merged t+y into ch).
